clinical_study.brief_title: Restoring High Dimensional Hand Function to Persons With Chronic High Tetraplegia
clinical_study.official_title: Restoring High Dimensional Hand Function to Persons With Chronic High Tetraplegia

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock: This study is for people who have a paralyzed arm and hand from a spinal cord injury, who have also received a recording electrode array in the brain as part of the BrainGate study. The study will look at the ability of these participants to control different grasping patterns of the hand, both in virtual reality and in his/her actual hand. Movement of the participant's hand is controlled by a functional electrical stimulation (FES) system, which involves small electrodes implanted in the arm, shoulder and hand that use small electrical currents to activate the appropriate muscles.

primary_outcome.measure: Ability to form appropriate grasp patterns
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, typically around 1 year
primary_outcome.description: The success rate for achieving a series of specified grasp patterns will be calculated. This will be a percentage of the target grasp patterns successfully achieved.

arm_group.description: Participants will be asked to think about holding different shaped objects, and the recorded cortical signal patterns will be decoded to match those grasp shapes

intervention.intervention_name: Using the Neuroport cortical recording array to determine the desired grasp pattern for a functional electrical stimulation (FES) system
intervention.description: Participants will be asked to think about holding different shaped objects, and the recorded cortical signal patterns will be decoded to match those grasp shapes

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Cognitively intact (able to follow instructions)
- A spinal cord injury resulting in at least partial arm paralysis
- Participant in BrainGate2 clinical trial, having already received an intracortical array and demonstrated the ability to use the neural signals to control a cursor on a monitor.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Profound visual impairments
- Participant in BrainGate2 clinical trial with insufficient recordable neural signals (such that the researchers cannot decode a movement intention command signal)
